model_response.text:
The founders of Viaweb, a startup founded by Paul Graham, wanted to create a web-based platform that would allow users to create online stores. The founders, who had previously worked on other projects, knew that they needed a system that could handle complex tasks such as customer management and payment processing. They decided to hire a group of freelancers, including Richard Dagen, who was known for his expertise in online commerce. This move was met with skepticism by some, as they questioned the usefulness of freelancers and the value they could bring to a business.

The founders were also aware of the challenges of scaling a startup, particularly when it comes to marketing and management. They decided to take a different approach, which involved using a batch model to fund startups instead of individual investors. This involved setting up a summer program to identify new startups and offer financial support to them in exchange for equity. The batch model allowed them to focus on solving specific problems and building relationships with potential investors.

The founders also wanted to create a more open and transparent approach to design and research. They wanted to focus on the user, rather than just designing for their own interests. This involved taking risks and experimenting with new ideas, rather than just testing a product that was perfect. The founders also wanted to make things happen, not just wait for results. They believed in continuous improvement and wanted to iterate and refine their products through iteration and experimentation.

The founders believed that good design was all about making things for humans, rather than just for humans. They wanted to create software that would be useful and enjoyable to use. They took this approach to the world of oil painting, where artists often had to use a different set of brushes and paints than others.

The founders also believed in collaboration and that good design should involve multiple people working together. They experimented with different approaches, such as the "Worse is Better" concept, which involved building prototypes before launching a product. They believed that this approach was a better way to create software than just testing a product through iteration and experimentation.

The founders also believed in asking users the right questions and assuming that they knew best about their needs. They did not want to ask users what they did or what they needed from a product. Instead, they wanted to design something that would make users happy and make the work easier for them. They took the time to understand the user and their needs, and they did not want to be asked to fix problems that they had not known.
